description: {"blocks":[{"key":"a6g0e","text":"BACKGROUND","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfmj7","text":"As databases grow larger, it becomes harder to fully control their collection, and they frequently come with missing values: incomplete observations. These large databases are well suited to train machine-learning models, for instance for forecasting or to extract biomarkers in biomedical settings. Such predictive approaches can use discriminative --rather than generative-- modeling, and thus open the door to new missing-values strategies. Yet existing empirical evaluations of strategies to handle missing values have focused on inferential statistics.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7rcc8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eu91g","text":"RESULTS","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1r8a9","text":"Here we conduct a systematic benchmark of missing-values strategies in predictive models with a focus on large health databases: four electronic health record datasets, a population brain imaging one, a health survey and two intensive care ones. Using gradient-boosted trees, we compare native support for missing values with simple and state-of-the-art imputation prior to learning. We investigate prediction accuracy and computational time. For prediction after imputation, we find that adding an indicator to express which values have been imputed is important, suggesting that the data are missing not at random. Elaborate missing values imputation can improve prediction compared to simple strategies but requires longer computational time on large data. Learning trees that model missing values --with missing incorporated attribute-- leads to robust, fast, and well-performing predictive modeling.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"92cb8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bi546","text":"CONCLUSIONS","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aj1cl","text":"Native support for missing values in supervised machine learning predicts better than state-of-the-art imputation with much less computational cost. When using imputation, it is important to add indicator columns expressing which values have been imputed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"4q828","text":"This protocol details the experiments run in the GigaScience article Benchmarking missing-values approaches for predictive models on health databases, Perez-Lebel et al. 2022. The code used for running the experiments and plotting the results is available on GitHub: https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":69,"length":80}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":267,"length":54}],"data":{}},{"key":"9fbr2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"43n4s","text":"Accessing the databases can be time consuming. We published our detailed results in CSV files to allow further analysis of our results without needing to access the data: https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches/blob/2ed30c0ffffa93f0398731b11b9202523c4da96f/scores/merged_scores.csv.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":171,"length":125}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"C5205C3C720C11EC90210A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"7B8CCE5072CE11EC90210A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches/blob/2ed30c0ffffa93f0398731b11b9202523c4da96f/scores/merged_scores.csv"}}}}
keywords: ,Missing Values, Machine Learning, Supervised Learning, Benchmark, Imputation,Multiple Imputation,Bagging

references.title: Logistic Regression with Missing Covariates -- Parameter Estimation, Model Selection and Prediction within a Joint-Modeling Framework
references.authors: Wei Jiang, Julie Josse, Marc Lavielle, TraumaBase Group

references.title: Polygenic prediction of breast cancer: comparison of genetic predictors and implications for risk stratification
references.authors: Kristi Läll, Maarja Lepamets, Marili Palover, Tõnu Esko, Andres Metspalu, Neeme Tõnisson, Peeter Padrik, Reedik Mägi, Krista Fischer

status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6r3rm","text":"This protocol details the experiments run in the GigaScience article Benchmarking missing-values approaches for predictive models on health databases, Perez-Lebel et al. 2022. The code used for running the experiments and plotting the results is available on GitHub:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":69,"length":80}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2r0cg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8tmqg","text":"And can be installed through the following steps:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cm1uc","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"941cd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"software","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":0,"developer":"Alexandre Perez-Lebel","guid":"D4DF4500028511EB9BD06762C633C9D3","id":1121,"link":"","name":"Benchmarking missing-values approaches for predictive models...","os_name":null,"os_version":null,"repository":"https://github.com/alexprz/article-benchmark_mv_approaches","version":null}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"id":9892,"name":"git clone https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches.git\ncd benchmark_mv_approaches\nconda install --file requirements.txt","os_name":null,"os_version":null,"command_name":"Install","description":"Download and install the code reproducing the experiments.","can_edit":1,"guid":"74748020DE6411EB948159362D7696E5"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5ccfl","text":"We benchmarked 12 supervised predictive methods on 13 prediction tasks taken from 4 health databases.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ihjg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4mklo","text":"Each one of the 4 databases needs to be downloaded separately from their respective source project. Access to Traumabase, UK BioBank and MIMIC-III, requires an application. NHIS is freely available. Once downloaded, data path of each database can be updated in the TB.py, UKBB.py, MIMIC.py and NHIS.py files which are in the database/ folder of the project.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":325,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":265,"length":5},{"key":1,"offset":272,"length":8},{"key":2,"offset":281,"length":8},{"key":3,"offset":294,"length":7}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"36888410DE6D11EB948159362D7696E5","url":"https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches/blob/196e33cfd6151a91aa7ab62ca0f1c59db7f61b83/database/TB.py#L15"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"427864C0DE6D11EB948159362D7696E5","url":"https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches/blob/196e33cfd6151a91aa7ab62ca0f1c59db7f61b83/database/UKBB.py#L14"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"60D119D0DE6D11EB948159362D7696E5","url":"https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches/blob/196e33cfd6151a91aa7ab62ca0f1c59db7f61b83/database/MIMIC.py#L14"}},"3":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"4DC94650DE6D11EB948159362D7696E5","url":"https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches/blob/196e33cfd6151a91aa7ab62ca0f1c59db7f61b83/database/NHIS.py#L13"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2h8ml","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e98qm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"boej9","text":"The Traumabase Group (TB) is a collaboration studying major trauma. The database gathers information from 20 French trauma centers on more than 20 000 trauma cases from admission until discharge from critical care. Data collection started in 2010 and is still ongoing in 2020. We used records spanning from 2010 to 2019. We defined 5 prediction tasks on this database, 4 classifications and 1 regression. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c8gnr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1c7p1","text":"Data can be obtained by contacting the team on the Traumabase website.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":24,"length":45}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"dataset","mutability":"","data":{"id":606,"link":"http://www.traumabase.eu/en_US","name":"Traumabase","can_edit":1,"guid":"CE770413DE6611EBBB040A58A9FEAC02"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"44D655A0DE6F11EBBB040A58A9FEAC02","url":"http://www.traumabase.eu/en_US/contact"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"el824","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8t20j","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"g4s5","text":"UK Biobank (UKBB) is a major prospective epidemiology cohort with biomedical measurements. It provides health information on more than 500 000 United-Kingdom participants aged between 40 to 69 years from 2006 to 2010. We defined 5 tasks on this database, 4 classifications and 1 regression.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8949f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"acafd","text":"The data are available upon application as detailed on the UK BioBank website.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":40,"length":37}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"dataset","mutability":"","data":{"id":607,"link":"https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/","name":"UKBB","can_edit":1,"guid":"DF54F3F5DE6611EBBB040A58A9FEAC02"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"362BA6A6DE6F11EBBB040A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/register-apply/"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"14iqe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"44qih","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"5ifar","text":"The Medical Information Mart for Intensive Care (MIMIC) database is an Intensive Care Unit (ICU) dataset developed by the MIT Lab for Computational Physiology. It comprises deidentified health data associated with about 60 000 ICU admissions recorded at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center of Boston, United States, between 2001 and 2012. It includes demographics, vital signs, laboratory tests, medications, and more. We defined 2 classification tasks on this database. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"begas","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"26ts7","text":"The data can be accessed via an application described on the MIMIC website. Note that, as of the time of writing, the completion of an online MIT course is required for the application. We used the 1.4 version of the data in the project.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":29,"length":46}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"dataset","mutability":"","data":{"id":608,"link":"https://mimic.physionet.org/","name":"MIMIC-III (v1.4)","can_edit":1,"guid":"E976C383DE6611EBBB040A58A9FEAC02"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"2C79E34DDE6F11EBBB040A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://mimic.physionet.org/gettingstarted/access"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"o5rb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4eav2","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"c6sso","text":"The National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) is a major data collection program of the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS), part of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in the United States. It aims to monitor the health of the population. Since 1957, it collects data from United-States population. We used the 2017 edition, summing up to approximately 35 000 households containing about 87 500 persons. We defined 1 regression task on this database.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aqttn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"admcp","text":"It is freely-accessible on the NHIS website.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":6,"length":38}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"dataset","mutability":"","data":{"id":609,"link":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nhis/nhis_2017_data_release.htm","name":"NHIS (2017)","can_edit":1,"guid":"EF2686A5DE6611EBBB040A58A9FEAC02"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"0F4F4615DEFD11EBBB040A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nhis/nhis_2017_data_release.htm"}}}}

The list of their IDs and names can be obtained running:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"92tn4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"din69","text":"IDs and names of the available methods are: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5cbf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dk8c1","text":"Classification and Regression code respectively for HistGradientBoostingClassifier and HistGradientBoostingRegressor from scikit-learn. Classification_Logit and Regression_Ridge code respectively for linear models Logit and Ridge used in the supplementary experiment. To each of these 4 base codes can be appended the name of an imputer (eg _imuted_Mean, _Imputed_Med, ...) with or without the mask (eg _imuted_Mean, _Imputed_Mean+mask, ...). Whether to use Bagging can be specified later as explained in the Prediction section of this {"blocks":[{"key":"9qqa7","text":"11 tasks have their features automatically selected with a simple ANOVA-based univariate test of the link of each feature to the outcome (task name ends with \"_pvals\" in the code and \"_screening\" in the article). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8vh6o","text":"The 2 remaining tasks have their feature manually defined following the choices of experts in prior studies. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fr8mc","text":"ANOVA-based feature selection","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4imsf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56le6","text":"Categorical features are first one-hot encoded. Then, the ANOVA-based univariate test is performed on one third of the samples which are then discarded. We kept the 100 encoded features having the smallest 100 p-values. Once the features are selected, the cross-validated prediction is performed on the remaining two thirds of the samples. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4db69","text":"For these tasks, there are 5 trials during which the samples on which the selection test is performed are redrawn, and the prediction each time fitted on the new remaining samples and the new selected features.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eti2c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f3d2b","text":"We used f_classif and f_regression from the feature_selection module of scikit-learn.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":8,"length":9},{"style":"italic","offset":22,"length":12},{"style":"italic","offset":44,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9rd3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65bc5","text":"For each of these tasks, p-values of the test can be computed for each trial by running:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1avdt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f2ko6","text":"Be careful to replace placeholders {task_name} and {T} by the name of the task and the trial ID (0 to 4) respectively.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c91vn","text":"Example:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"28sqk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e3qov","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fbrk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2dp76","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"id":9895,"name":"python main.py select {task_name} --T {T}","os_name":null,"os_version":null,"command_name":"Feature selection","description":"Compute p-values of ANOVA-based test to select features","can_edit":1,"guid":"65A54FB9DF0B11EBBB040A58A9FEAC02"}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"id":9896,"name":"python main.py select TB/death_pvals --T 0","os_name":null,"os_version":null,"command_name":"Example of feature selection","description":"Compute p-values of ANOVA-based test to select features of the task TB/death_pvals on the first trial.","can_edit":1,"guid":"BD17C7B0DF1D11EBAAC78D4B9C52DA16"}},"2":{"type":"safety","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bctdh","text":"Note {"blocks":[{"key":"50fm0","text":"Manual selection following experts","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"30e1d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"570of","text":"Features for the hemorrhagic shock prediction (task named TB/hemo) in the Traumabase database are defined following Jiang et al.:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bqf13","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b4ic9","text":"Features for the breast cancer prediction (task named UKBB/breast_25) are defined following Läll et al.:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9dhd","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fo0v0","text":"There is only 1 trial for these tasks.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Wei Jiang, Julie Josse, Marc Lavielle, TraumaBase Group","can_edit":1,"date":"1588326180","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1016/j.csda.2019.106907","guid":"E60E8B10DF0711EBAEA2FF381FAEA508","id":1174,"journal":"Computational Statistics and Data Analysis","protocol_id":null,"title":"Logistic Regression with Missing Covariates -- Parameter Estimation, Model Selection and Prediction within a Joint-Modeling Framework"}},"1":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Kristi Läll, Maarja Lepamets, Marili Palover, Tõnu Esko, Andres Metspalu, Neeme Tõnisson, Peeter Padrik, Reedik Mägi, Krista Fischer","can_edit":1,"date":"1560160080","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1186/s12885-019-5783-1","guid":"EFEE5B00DF0811EBAEA2FF381FAEA508","id":1175,"journal":"BMC Cancer","protocol_id":null,"title":"Polygenic prediction of breast cancer: comparison of genetic predictors and implications for risk stratification"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7becb","text":"Scale","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5rbkj","text":"To study the influence of the scale on the results, we decided to work on 4 sizes of the training set: 2 500, 10 000, 25 000 and 100 000. For each one of these sizes are run the following operations.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4dpn9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37m60","text":"Nested cross-validations","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dvg8i","text":"Two nested cross-validations are used. The outer one yields 5 training and test sets. The training set has 2 500, 10 000, 25 000 or 100 000 samples depending on the scale. The test set is composed of all the remaining samples. Note that the size of the test set is considerably larger with a train set of 2 500 samples than with 100 000. On each training set, we perform a cross-validated hyper-parameter search –the inner cross-validation– and select the best hyper-parameters. We evaluate the best model on the respective test set. We assess the quality of the prediction with a coefficient of determination for regressions and the area under the ROC curve for classification. We average the scores obtained on the 5 test sets of the outer cross-validation to give the final score.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6h3tl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bucr2","text":"The test set size is at least 10% the size of the training set. If a prediction task has not enough samples once the feature selection is performed (eg 110 000 samples for the 100 000 scale), it is skipped for the corresponding scale. As a result the biggest scale has fewer available tasks than the smallest one (resp. 4 against 13).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fk7j1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ic25","text":"To draw the 5 folds, we used StratifiedShuffleSplit (resp. ShuffleSplit) from scikit-learn for classifications (resp. regressions). We used GridSearchCV from scikit-learn to perform the cross-validated hyper-parameters tuning.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":29,"length":22},{"style":"italic","offset":59,"length":12},{"style":"italic","offset":140,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bqrns","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26bn8","text":"Evaluating a method on a prediction task is done by running:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bsi9m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cuhc3","text":"Be careful to replace placeholders {task_name}, {method_id} and {T} by the name of the task, the ID or name of the method and the trial ID (0 to 4) respectively.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"29nqg","text":"Example:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ohr8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eep3q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1p0h","text":"Some methods of the benchmark use bagging. To add bagging to an available method, specify the number of estimators you want in the ensemble with the nbagging option. For instance:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":149,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d5vrh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2o9dq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f5g76","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"29bkn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ek80l","text":"Results are dumped in the results/ folder.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":26,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"663fb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5hbun","text":"To run the full benchmark of the article, we needed 520 000 CPU hours.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b48dv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1icvn","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"id":9897,"name":"python main.py predict {task_name} {method_id} --T {T}","os_name":null,"os_version":"","command_name":"Prediction","description":"Benchmark a method on a prediction task","can_edit":1,"guid":"9EFAC7A0DF1311EBAEA2FF381FAEA508"}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"id":9898,"name":"python main.py predict TB/death_pvals 0 --T 0","os_name":null,"os_version":null,"command_name":"Prediction example","description":"Benchmark method with ID 0 on the task TB/death_pvals on the trial 0.","can_edit":1,"guid":"542198C0DF1411EBAEA2FF381FAEA508"}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"id":9903,"name":"python main.py predict TB/death_pvals 0 --T 0 --nbagging 100","os_name":null,"os_version":null,"command_name":"Prediction with bagging","description":"Benchmark method with ID 0 bagged with 100 base estimators, on the task TB/death_pvals on the trial 0.","can_edit":1,"guid":"B2CA3900722011ECBA7A5B9E24D444A3"}},"3":{"type":"safety","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"qf09","text":"Note that these commands will fail without the data and without the types of the features.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"4":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":1872000000,"guid":"A3EE6EE0721311ECBA7A5B9E24D444A3","id":0,"label":"CPU hours to run the full benchmark","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7m2bt","text":"Imputation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d22uo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aqlim","text":"5 imputation methods are available:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2gf8v","text":"Imputation with the mean.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d8qee","text":"Imputation with the median.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ch9mg","text":"Iterative imputation.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"526uk","text":"Imputation with the nearest neighbors.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ug3a","text":"Multiple Imputation using Bagging.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"52ied","text":"For each of them, new binary features can be added to the data. This binary mask encodes whether a value was originally missing or not.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"olk8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cnhre","text":"The imputer is fitted on the train set only and both the train and test sets are then imputed with the fitted imputer. Doing so avoids leaking information from the train set to the test set and then helps to avoid overfitting.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ukft","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eoh3i","text":"We used SimpleImputer, IterativeImputer, KNNImputer, BaggingClassifier and BaggingRegressor from scikit-learn.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":8,"length":13},{"style":"italic","offset":23,"length":17},{"style":"italic","offset":41,"length":50}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6kgel","text":"Once the results of all the methods are obtained, they are gathered in a single CSV file using the following command:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fqrk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f0sce","text":"This creates a scores.csv file in the scores/ folder.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":15,"length":10},{"style":"italic","offset":38,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"53v7p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"m4li","text":"The aggregated results obtained during our experiment are given in our repository. This allows to reproduce the figures and tables and to analyze further the results without needing the original data.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":83}],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":54,"length":28}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"id":9899,"name":"python main.py aggregate --root results/","os_name":null,"os_version":null,"command_name":"Aggregate results","description":"Merge all results in a single csv file","can_edit":1,"guid":"096E24E0DF1611EBAEA2FF381FAEA508"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"EEA753B0DF1611EBAEA2FF381FAEA508","url":"https://github.com/aperezlebel/benchmark_mv_approaches/blob/2ed30c0ffffa93f0398731b11b9202523c4da96f/scores/merged_scores.csv"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c3s8q","text":"Most of the figures and tables of our article can be easily reproduced without requiring the original data (based on saved results only). Use commands defined in the Makefile to easily reproduce figures and tabs. (Note that some commands will fail because they require data or raw results that are not available in the repository).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":166,"length":8}],"data":{}},{"key":"9rs8n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4eitg","text":"All
